verses.text: The word of the Lord came to Jonah a second time, saying:
verses.comment: God's initiative with Jonah is repeated, showing divine persistence and mercy. Compare to prophetic calls throughout Scripture. God calls even those who previously resisted.

verses.text: "Arise, go to Nineveh, that great city, and proclaim to it the message that I tell you."
verses.comment: Nineveh is highlighted as 'great,' implying its importance and the vastness of God’s mercy. Significant parallel to Jesus' commission to his disciples.

verses.text: So Jonah arose and went to Nineveh according to the word of the Lord. Now Nineveh was an exceedingly large city, a three days’ journey in breadth.
verses.comment: Jonah’s obedience contrasts his previous flight. The mention of 'three days’ journey' may foreshadow Jesus' three days in the tomb (see Matt. 12:40), which ties the narrative to Christ's resurrection.

verses.text: Jonah began to enter the city, going a day’s journey, and he cried out, "Yet forty days, and Nineveh will be overthrown!"
verses.comment: The term 'forty days' signals a period of testing and repentance (see Noah's flood, Jesus' fasting). God often uses such periods for transformation.

verses.text: And the people of Nineveh believed God. They proclaimed a fast and put on sackcloth, from the greatest of them to the least.
verses.comment: Repentance is shown by hearts turned to God and external acts—even fasting and sackcloth—for all people, echoing communal acts of penance found elsewhere. Note how true repentance involves both belief and action.

verses.text: When the word reached the king of Nineveh, he rose from his throne, took off his robe, covered himself with sackcloth, and sat in ashes.
verses.comment: The king’s humble response is reminiscent of Old Testament leaders showing humility before God. Leadership in repentance sets an example for all—a theme echoed in Christ’s call to humility and self-emptying.

verses.text: He issued a proclamation and published it throughout Nineveh: "By the decree of the king and his nobles: No man or animal, herd or flock, shall taste anything; let them not eat or drink water."
verses.comment: Fasting is imposed universally, even upon animals, emphasizing total communal repentance. The unity of external practices in seeking God’s mercy subtly reinforces the value of corporate worship and shared penance.

verses.text: "But let man and animal be covered in sackcloth, and let everyone call urgently on God. Let each turn away from their evil ways and from the violence in their hands."
verses.comment: Genuine repentance combines external actions and interior conversion. Notice the use of 'call urgently,' indicating intercessory prayer, which is modeled in the assembly of believers throughout Scripture.

verses.text: "Who knows? God may turn and relent, and turn away from his fierce anger, so that we may not perish."
verses.comment: The call for mercy acknowledges that salvation is a gift, not a right—relying on God’s gracious response. The hope for God’s mercy through repentance is a theme that continues in the New Testament (see Luke 15:7).

verses.text: When God saw what they did, how they turned from their evil ways, God relented from the disaster that he had said he would bring upon them, and he did not do it.
verses.comment: This verse affirms God’s readiness to forgive those who turn from sin. The act of communal repentance leads to divine mercy, demonstrating God’s love for all nations. Spiritual transformation brings forth real change—an image fulfilled in Christ’s call for all people to repentance and life.
